page.title: 04RIVER (SAFETY AND FLOODS)
page.content: The{River Kent}was prone to flooding in the years{1831-1960},so in{1970}the Lancashire River Authority decided to design a{Flood Prevention Scheme}by widening the 81m wide river to 135m wide to prevent flood damage to property. Work started in{1972}and they worked in six phases,working from Beezon Field down to Watercrook. Without this scheme floods like the{ {1954}flood might have been repeated, and in that flood 10,000 cubic feet of water passed per second, but the maximum flood occurring since the prevention scheme has been 7,000 cubic feet per second. The water running through the Kent is tested regularly for signs of effluent from a papermill.But now they have a new sewerage system which neutralises the effluent and then it is put in the river.
